siteMetadata.title: Apollo GraphQL Docs
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using Apollo Server

children.value: can be done in many ways. One simple way is to use ApolloServer's
method to directly execute a GraphQL operation without going through a full HTTP operation.
Integration testing a GraphQL server means testing many things.
has a request pipeline that can support many plugins that can affect the way an operation is executed. The
method provides a single hook to run operations through the request pipeline, enabling the most thorough tests possible without starting up an HTTP server.
For example, you can set up a full server with your schema and resolvers and run an operation against it.
// create a test server to test against, using our production typeDefs,
// mock the dataSource's underlying fetch methods
// run query against the server and snapshot the output
This is an example of a full integration test being run against a test instance of
. This test imports the important pieces to test (
) and creates a new instance of
The example above shows writing a test-specific
which provides data directly instead of calculating it from the request context. If you'd like to use your server's real
function, you can pass a second argument to
which will be passed to your
function as its argument. You will need to put together an object with the
to execute queries and mutations. Because the interface matches the GraphQL HTTP protocol, you specify the operation text under the
key even if the operation is a mutation. You can specify
either as a string or as a
Note that errors in parsing, validating, and executing your operation are returned in the
field of the result (just like in a GraphQL response) rather than thrown.

properties.ariaLabel: createtestclient and apollo server testing permalink

children.value: There is also a package called
. This API does not support the second context-function-argument argument, and doesn't provide any real advantages over calling
directly. It is deprecated and will no longer be published with Apollo Server 3.
We recommend that you replace this code:
Instead of bypassing the HTTP layer, you may just want to fully run your server and test it with a real HTTP client.
Apollo Server doesn't have any built-in support for this. You can combine any HTTP or GraphQL client such as
to run operations against your server. There are also community packages available such as
which provides an API similar to the deprecated
package which uses mocked Express request and response objects.
